Pursuant to authority vested in the undersigned Trustee by vir tue of that certain Deed of Trust dated July 15th, 1960, executed by R. L. Burke, Jr., of record on July 27th, 1960, in the Clerks Office of the Circuit Court of Ap pomattox County, Va., in D. B. 72, at Page 308, that whereas, default having been made in the payment of the indebtedness therein secured, and upon re quest by the holder of said obli gation that said Trust be execut ed, and in conformity therewith, the following real estate will be offered for sale in compliance with the terms and conditions of aforementioned instrument. Description Parcel No I All of that one-fourteenth 1- 14 undivided interest in the local dwelling house property, known as the R. F. Burke, Es tate,- located in the Town of Appomattox, Virginia, fronting on Railroad Street, bordering on Burke Street, adjoining the real estate of Mrs. W. R. Lizzie Reynolds, J. C. Cald well, Jr., et als and the C. S. Jenkins, estate Parcel No2 All of that one-half 1-2 un divided interest in the local dwelling house property of the late R. L. Burke, deceased, lo cated in the Town of Appo mattox, Virginia, fronting on Lee - Grant Avenue, contain ing 0.6597 of an acre, more or less, adjoining the real estate of Moses, formerly Mrs. Ethel F. Purdum on the Southeast, Wm. W.  Emily H. Burke on the Southwest and Northwest. Parcel No 2 is subject to a Prior Lien of 2,300.19, which includes interest to August 30th 1963. document.text: We are pained to chronicle the death jf one of our prominent and honored citizens Mrs. HalloweH, who died in the village at the home of her son, R. F Burke, on Mon day March 5th, 196, in the 79th year of her age. The deceased was a member of that prominent family of Irbys of Nottoway and was twice marled, Her first marriage was to Dr- R. H. Burke, of Prince Edward and in 1867 she married Wm. H . HalloweH, of King William, who died in 1892. She had two chil dren by her first husband and none by her last marriage. She is sur vived by her son, R. F. Burke, of this place, and two brothers, Walter M. Irby and Geo. W. Irby, one sis ter, Mrs. Virginia F . Jones, all of Nottoway. The deceased was a consecrat d Christian character aud her life was full of good works she was for 50 years a member of the Method ist church, and iu her younger day gave the best of her life to the work of her master, and when the end came she was read for her reward. She was a warm friend and a com-

document.text: ward LeGrand,  Sr., died very suddenly of heart disease, at his home three miles oast of here. Mr, LeGrand, a few dys before, attempted to hew some rai road ties near his residence, and had the mis fortune to cut his knee very badly with the axe this, however, was net the cause if his death. It has been known for years that his heart wasseriously affected, and while his death was a great shook to . his relatives and friends, they have rather xpected that the end would come sud- lenly. His father and one of iiis brothers jassed away in the same mannerwith, mt a moments warningfrom heart disease. The deceased was 62 years of vge, and had spent his whole life in this his native county. He comes from one of the old Virginia families, and is tho last son of fifteen children horn unto Caroline Hunter and Archer Alex. Lc- ttvand. He connected himself with Lib erty Baptist church when quite a young man _ 45 years ago, and his walk in life has been upright and correct, full of Christian love for his neighbor and fel- lcwman. It is said there are only two other members of Liberty who have wor shipped with the church longer than the deceased,  ind they a-r Messrs. M. H. Golem an and T. H. A. Clieathain. Hu served the Confederacy with distinction to himself and fidelity to the cause. He was several times wounded, and was promoted to theoffice Lieutenant for bravery am.proticcn cy. He has held positions of honor and trust j since the war. the latest position that of Sup- I intcmlcut oi the County Aims House and farm, in all of these positions lii .1 character, shown out as a great power and influence for good. Thirty-six years ago he married Mi6S Sarah Ann Smithsister of T. A. Smith, of this place. As a result of this marriage six child rensurvive him, together with his widow as d II ows ! Mrs. IV. M. Hancock,of this piu.cvj  E. LeGrand, Jr., Evergreen Mrs. W. A. Keilv, Crewe L. B. LeGrand, Lynchburg, Ya. Mis. W. D. Mason, Pam pi in City, and Josiah LeGrand, who remainsst horn. lie. s also survived by live sister Mrs. C. V Hancock, Mrs. C. A. Abbitt, of this place Mrs. S. H. Kelly, of Crewe Mrs. W. H.Iiay- ick, of Washington, D. t, and Mrs. Kh-.h- d Bright, of Kansas City, Mo. His funeral was preached by his pastor, Dr. G. B. Taylor, to a large assemblage of sorrowing friends and relatives in a tender and consoling style, and the interment was had Tuesday evening at Liberty Cemetery in the presence of a large crowd of his old friends. The pall-bearers were J. R. Atwood, K. F. Burke, R. 8. Jenkins, H. W. McKinney, J. F. Dickerson, and Jennings Ferguson. George T. Peers, Jno. G. Fisher and Misses Vera Burke and Virgilia Atwood sang a very appropriate song. The sod never rested over a nobler charuc ter than Ned LeGrand. He w as our friend he was a friend to everybody. There is none to take his place.

document.text: Voters will also vote for three Justices of Peace and one Con stable in each district. You wil also vote for one Overseer Poor in each district. There will be no name on the ticket for Senator, Clerk of Court or Sheriff-these gentle men have no. opposition and have been declared the nominees of the party. Four years ago the judges election excluded 147 voters who did not answer questions to the judges satisfactorily touching their right to vote in the pri mary. There was a filed con test by A R. Harwood and A H. Clement who claimed that they were honestly elected, but the court sustained the ruling of the Committee and the judges and awarded the election to R. F. Burke and Joel W Flood. Had the 147 votes been count ed as sworn to be cast for Har wood and Clement, Harwood would have had a majority over Mr. Burke of 31 votes and Clement a majority over Mr. Flood of 53 votes. It is claimed for most of the 147 excluded voters four years ago, that they have unquestion ably purged them elves of every objection by voting the Democratic ticket at general elections for four years. Upon challenge any voter who can say that at the last general election November inwhich he or she voted they voted the Dem ocratic ticket and will support the Democratic ticket at nxt election shall be allowed to vote and no judge of election who re gards his oath of office will do anything to deprive such person of the right to vote. All persons qualified to vote in the primary, should register and cast a vote in this important election. There are more than 2300 eligible voters on the list as tax-payers, and it is expected that 2,000 of them will go to the polls on election day. With such a vote cast no man can complain of the expression rendered for or against him.

Burke- Misses Vay Abbitt, Vernie Oden Elaine McDearmon, Mrs. Ola Furbushand Miss Eddie Hardy went to Roanoke, aid Spencer and Bradley Babcock also went. Senator Ferguson and Clerk Smith are attending meeting of Highway Commission in Char lottesville this week, armed with petitions to the Commission to recognize the Bent Creek to Phenix highway which is oric.Qf the greatest road projects for Central Virginia. Tfiis road will connect with the short route to Richmond, Buchingham C. H., Nelson C. H -, Charlotte C. H. and Appomattox C. H. It will serve a great territory and be of great convenience to a lage num ber of people.

Such capable men constitute the Directors and managing officers of the Bank of Appomattox. Consider for a moment what an advantage it is to hare such an in stitution in our midst. Instead of going to Lynchburg, Farmville or Richmond fur banking facilities, you now have here at home, and at your very door, a safe and sound in stitution where the farrns, mer chants, lawyers and doctors can transact their business  make their deposits draw their checks  pur chase exchange upon New York or London  and draw interest upon their certificates of deposit. IFhy should not all this surround ing country do its dealings with the Bank of Appomattox ? The first requisite in securing such patron age is that of confidence. Well, could better assurance, of absolute security and safety be guaranteed than in the names of the gentlemen who are to conduct the business of the hank? Who are they? First and foremost,foremost because he will be chiefly hi charge of the financial operations of the bankis R. F. Burke, the cashier, lie has been here in our midst for twenty nine years as railroad agent at this place. His character for honesty, integrity and business capacity, is known and read of all men. document.text: The remains of H. D Flood now rest in bis native county. Sunday morning a private car bearing the remains and im mediate members of bis family arrived here from Washington, where the remains  have been resting in a private vault for b year, he having died thereon December 8 th, 1921. When the train reached here r.he Masons took charge of the oodythe following acted as pall bearers Col. Joseph But ton, R. F. Burke, L. F. Fergu- jon, J. R. Horseley, H C. Bab cock, W. P. Gills, B. F. OJen, L. E Smith and W. a . Moses, A great crowd .followed the remains to Liberty Baptist church, where Mrs. Trinkle, wife of Gov. Trinkle, rendered several violin solos she was accompanied by Miss Kate Franklin at piano A special choir rendered several very sweet selections. Rev. W. W. PippeD, pastor of the Presbyterian church, to which the deceased belonged had charge of the services and introduced Hon. S L. Ferguson, who in turn introduced U. S. Senator Swanson, the orator of the day. Mr. Swanson, who studied with the deceased at U. Va., served witn him in Congress, and waged together many fierce political battles in the State, spoke for an hour of the virtues of his departed .friend and at limes was eloquent as he pictured the careers of the leading statesmen of Virginia among whom he placed the late Representative Flood.  He was an aggressive lead er, cheered and loved by an enthusiastic fo lowing. He hewed his way to the fiont with the battle axe of a warrior. He despised preferments ob tained by the insinuating arts of the demagogue. His chosen piace of action was on the field of battle and not in the cloister of intrigue and diplomacy. He was the Rupert of the Virginia democracy, bold, courageous and darin . Be cheerfully and proudly wore scars obtained by fidelity to friendship or for a cause espoused. He possessed a persistency and perseverance of purpose which would have attained dis tinction in any vocation of life selected. When he reached a conclusion in the oourse of life no obstacles could deter him in continuous effort to reach the attainment. He was the per sonification of tireless energy and determined effort. He hammered, hammered a n d hammered until success came. His industry waB as much an elemept in hiB success as were his moral and intellectual qualities. From early youth to death his life was one of cease less activity. This sapped the foundations of a constitution phenominal in its robustness and strength, and occasioned his early death.

document.text: The new school at Oakville held ta first commencement exeroiaes on the 3rd, 4tb and 5th of April. The bonse was crowded to overflowing and mnoh enthusiasm was shown by the patrons as well as the pnpils. On Sunday night the 3rd, Rev. H. T. Allison preached a most ex cellent edncational sermon whioh was enjoyed by all present. On Monday night the small chil dren entertained the crowd with recitations, songs, drills and panto mimes. Master Dnrnard Thomas antomimed Old Black Joe, and also reeited A Burlesque on Wom ans Rights, whiebbrought down the house. Dnrnard is a talented boy and imitated a  darkey so well that some of the visitors really thonght he belonged to that race. After the exroisea Mr. R. F. Burke made a most interesting address on schools and the importance of ed ucation. He also presented the prises to the pnpils of the primary room. May. Harvey received the prize on spelling, Cornelia. Woodson, writing, Hettie Woodson, reading and Alex Btarria, arithmetic. On Tuesday night the grammar and high school department held 8way. The exeroise opened with America, whioh was snag and pantomimed by the school. Mr. James Lueado made the salutatory address which was enjoyed by all. James is a cool-headed speaker and haa talent that ie worth cultivating. Again, we had recitations, drill, marches, dialogues, pantomiems and tableanx. Special mention ahonld be made of Mr. William Albert Owen w h o declaimed Patrick Henrys famous speech end wcaclao valedictorian. He poaesses rare oratorical powers and held the au dience spellbound. At the beginning ot the session Hon. A. F. Thomas gave 10.00 with whioh to bay books as prises for the students. Midi Myrtle Thomas received the prises on geography and physiology, Miss Ethel Marsh on reading and com position, Miss Mary Harris, on grammar and arithmetic, Miss Go- lena Martin, composition, Mr. Tom Owen and Miss Myrtle Thomas tied tor the history prise, so it was divided between them. Mi sea Lois Lueado and Mary Harris each re ceived a prize on writing and Mr. William Albert Owen received the debaters prise. The scholarship mfcdal offered by Messrs. Ferguson, Owen and Thomas, was awarded to Miss Mary Harris. Prof. J. G. Fisher, of Stonewall High School delivered the medal. The music rendered by Messers. Edward and Lndwell Childress, on the violin and banjo added mnoh to the occasion These musicians are both talented and accomodating. The exercises closed with  Oakville High School, one of the school songs. The school made rapid progrrss daring the short time it was in ses sion only three months end thir teen days. Mnch credit is dne to the Principal Mias Frances Moss, and her sister Miss Mattie, in tbe training of these pupils. May this school grow better year by year and in time become one of the best in the State.

document.text: The late R. F. Burke was a be loved citizen of Appomattox Coun ty. He was first cashier of the Bank of Appomattox, serving from 1901 to 1912. In that year he was elected vice president as well as cashier and so served until 1917. He was execu tive vice president from 1917 to 1921, and became president in that year, and retained the office until his death in 1924.

document.text: The closing exercises of the High. School took place here Tuesday night, June the 1st, when principal Crawley deliv ered diplomas to 21 young ladies and men. The house, as usual, was overtaxed and not half of the crowd could get in the building.
